repnme.cdata!:
Zimbabwe - Park Rehabilitation and
            Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Park Rehabilitation and Conservation
            Project objective was to enhance the Government's
            ability to protect wildlife Populations, and their habitats,
            and to rehabilitate essential elements of infrastructure,
            strengthening the institutionalcapacity of agencies
            responsible for the sustainability of investments, and for
            the formulation of policy and implementation of wildlife
            programs. This Project Completion Note specifies the reasons
            for project cancellation as follows. The difficult economic
            and political crisis in Zimbabwe accelerated, with problems
            servicing  external debts, and by March 2000, the government
            defaulted on its loans to the Bank, and other international
            financial institutions. As a result, the Bank suspended
            disbursements on all projects in Zimbabwe on May 16,200O.
            The economic crisis worsened during the past four years, and
            the country's arrears continue to rise. Zimbabwe has
            not made any effort to clear its arrears to the Bank. The
            project was closed, and the undisbursed funds from both the
            Credit and Grant were cancelled on June 25, 2002 some 25
            months after the Bank suspended disbursements to Zimbabwe,
            as a result of the government's inability to service
            its loans to the Bank. The original closing date was 30
            September 2005.

repnme.cdata!:
Zimbabwe - Park Rehabilitation and
            Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Park Rehabilitation and Conservation
            Project aims to enhance Zimbabwe's ability to protect
            wildlife populations and their habitats and to develop the
            parks and wildlife sector. The project has three components.
            The first component reinforces institutional and
            organizational capacity to sustain investments and
            effectively manage the Parks estate and wildlife resources:
            it supports organizational development, implements Fund
            financial management and management information systems,
            institutes comprehensive park planning, improves capacity
            for policy development, supports monitoring and applied
            research for protected area management and biodiversity
            conservation, and provides interpretative and educational
            materials and programs. The second component improves
            elements of national park infrastructure needed to manage
            parks for wildlife and habitat conservation and for
            sustainable commercial development, including improving
            infrastructure critical for park functioning and tourism
            access, providing plant and equipment for road maintenance,
            improving and adding staff housing, and providing vehicles
            and other equipment for improved park management and
            anti-poaching operations. The third component strengthens
            biodiversity conservation in the national park and nearby
            areas; implements the park management plan; establishes a
            consultative process in park planning, management, and
            conservation; supports community-based sub-projects; and
            supports educational programs.
